prompt_init: You will receive a text. Your task is to rephrase this text without modifying its meaning. Just output your new text, nothing else. Here is the text:
prompt_update: You will receive a text. Your task is to rephrase this text without modifying its meaning. Just output your new text, nothing else. Here is the text:
initial_story:
The baby suffered a cardiac arrest at the theme park on Thursday

A woman has been arrested on suspicion of neglecting a five-month-old boy who suffered a cardiac arrest at a theme park.

The baby is in a critical condition in hospital following the incident at Legoland Windsor at about 13:00 BST on Thursday, police said.

A 27-year-old woman from Witham, Essex, was arrested on suspicion of neglecting a child to cause unnecessary injury.

She has been released on bail until 26 July.

Det Con Zoe Eele, of Thames Valley Police's Child Abuse Investigation Unit, said: "Firstly, our thoughts are with the family of the boy who is in a critical condition in hospital after suffering a cardiac arrest.

"We are working closely with the team at Legoland Windsor Resort but would like to speak to anyone who have information about this incident, specifically anyone who was queueing for the Coastguard HQ boat ride between around 11.30am and 12:45pm.

"I would ask for the public to please avoid speculation about the incident and to respect the boy's family at this deeply upsetting time."

Police said they are not looking for further suspects in relation to the incident.

In a statement, the theme park said: "On Thursday, a young guest was taken ill... and our fully trained First Aid team administered immediate care until the emergency services arrived.

"We will continue to support Thames Valley Police with their ongoing investigation."

Follow BBC South on Facebook, X, or Instagram. Send your story ideas to south.newsonline@bbc.co.uk or via WhatsApp on 0808 100 2240.

The BBC is not responsible for the content of external sites.

We are working closely with the team at Legoland Windsor Resort but would like to speak to anyone who have information about this incident, specifically anyone who was queueing for the Coastguard HQ boat ride between around 11.30am and 12:45pm. I would ask for the public to please avoid speculation about the incident and to respect the boy's family at this deeply upsetting time." Police are investigating an incident at Legoland Windsor Resort where a five-month-old baby went into cardiac arrest. The baby is currently in critical condition in hospital following the incident which happened around 1pm BST on Thursday. A 27-year-old woman from Witham, Essex has been arrested on suspicion of neglecting a child resulting in unnecessary injury. She has been released on bail until 26 July. Detective Constable Zoe Eele from the Thames Valley Police Child Abuse Investigation Unit said: "Our thoughts go out to the family of the young boy who remains in critical condition in hospital after suffering a cardiac arrest. We are working closely with the team at Legoland Windsor Resort but would like to speak to anyone who may have information about this incident, particularly those who were queueing for the Coastguard HQ boat ride between approximately 11.30am and 12:45pm. Please avoid speculating about what happened and respect the privacy of the boy's family during this difficult time." Police say they are not looking for any other suspects in relation to this incident. In a statement, the theme park said: "On Thursday, a young visitor became unwell and our fully trained first aid team provided immediate care until the emergency services arrived. We will continue to support Thames Valley Police with their ongoing investigation." Follow BBC South on Facebook, Twitter or Instagram. Thames Valley Police are investigating the sudden death of a 5-month-old child at Legoland Windsor Resort, England. According to reports, the infant went into cardiac arrest while visiting the theme park on Thursday afternoon. The baby is currently in critical condition in hospital after suffering a cardiac arrest. The parents of the child, a 27-year-old woman from Witham, Essex, have been arrested on suspicion of neglecting a child resulting in unnecessary injury. They have been released on bail until 26 July. Detective Constable Zoe Eele from the Thames Valley Police Child Abuse Investigation Unit said: "Our thoughts are with the family of the young boy who remains in critical condition in hospital after suffering a cardiac arrest. We are working closely with the team at Legoland Windsor Resort but would like to speak to anyone who may have information about this incident, particularly those who were queueing for the Coastguard HQ boat ride between approximately 11.30am and 12:45pm. Please avoid speculating about what happened and respect the privacy of the boy's family during this difficult time." Police say they are not looking for any other suspects in relation to this incident. In a statement, the theme park said: "On Thursday, a young visitor became unwell and our fully trained first aid team provided immediate care until the emergency services arrived. We will continue to support Thames Valley Police with their ongoing investigation." Follow BBC South on Facebook, Twitter or Instagram. If you have any story ideas, please send them to south.newsonline@bbc.co.uk or via WhatsApp at 0808 100 2240. The BBC is not responsible for the content of external sites.

The parents of the child, a 27-year-old woman from Witham, Essex, have been arrested on suspicion of neglecting a child resulting in unnecessary injury. They have been released on bail until 26 July. Detective Constable Zoe Eele from the Thames Valley Police Child Abuse Investigation Unit said: "Our thoughts are with the family of the young boy who remains in critical condition in hospital after suffering a cardiac arrest. We are working closely with the team at Legoland Windsor Resort but would like to speak to anyone who may have information about this incident, particularly those who were queueing for the Coastguard HQ boat ride between approximately 11.30am and 12:45pm. Please avoid speculating about what happened and respect the privacy of the boy's family during this difficult time." Police say they are not looking for any other suspects in relation to this incident. In a statement, the theme park said: "We will continue to support Thames Valley Police with their ongoing investigation." Follow BBC South on Facebook, Twitter or Instagram. If you have any story ideas, please send them to south.newsonline@bbc.co.uk or via WhatsApp at 0808 100 2240. The BBC is not responsible for the content of external sites.

A young child fell ill at the Legoland Windsor Resort on Thursday, prompting the theme park's first aid team to provide immediate assistance until emergency services arrived. The child's parents, a 27-year-old woman from Witham, Essex, have been arrested on suspicion of neglecting a child resulting in unnecessary injury. They have been released on bail until 26 July. Detective Constable Zoe Eele from the Thames Valley Police Child Abuse Investigation Unit stated, "Our thoughts are with the family of the young boy who remains in critical condition in hospital after suffering a cardiac arrest. We are working closely with the team at Legoland Windsor Resort but would like to speak to anyone who may have information about this incident, particularly those who were queueing for the Coastguard HQ boat ride between approximately 11.30am and 12:45pm. Please avoid speculating about what happened and respect the privacy of the boy's family during this difficult time." The police have confirmed that they are not looking for any other suspects in relation to this incident. The theme park issued a statement saying, "We will continue to support Thames Valley Police with their ongoing investigation." Follow BBC South on Facebook, Twitter or Instagram. If you have any story ideas, please send them to south.newsonline@bbc.co.uk or via WhatsApp at 0808 100 2240. The BBC is not responsible for the content of external sites.

A young child suffered a medical emergency while visiting the Legoland Windsor Resort on Thursday, requiring immediate attention from the park's first aid team. Emergency services were subsequently summoned to the scene. The child's parents, a 27-year-old woman from Witham, Essex, have been apprehended on suspicion of neglecting a child, leading to unnecessary harm. They have been released on bail pending further investigation, with a scheduled court date of 26 July. Detective Constable Zoe Eele of the Thames Valley Police Child Abuse Investigation Unit expressed her sympathies to the family of the young boy, who remains in critical condition in the hospital following a cardiac arrest. The police are working in conjunction with the Legoland Windsor Resort team to investigate the incident and are seeking information from anyone who was in the queue for the Coastguard HQ boat ride between approximately 11.30am and 12:45pm. The police have confirmed that they are not seeking any additional suspects in connection with the incident. The theme park has issued a statement declaring that it will continue to support Thames Valley Police in their ongoing investigation. Follow BBC South on Facebook, Twitter or Instagram for more updates on this developing story. If you have any story ideas, please contact us at south.newsonline@bbc.co.uk or via WhatsApp at 0808 100 2240. The BBC is not responsible for the content of external sites.

The child's parents, a 27-year-old woman from Witham, Essex, were arrested on suspicion of child neglect resulting in unnecessary harm and have been released on bail pending further investigation. A court date has been set for July 26. Detective Constable Zoe Eele of the Thames Valley Police Child Abuse Investigation Unit expressed her sympathies to the family of the young boy, who remains in critical condition in the hospital after suffering a cardiac arrest. The police are working with the Legoland Windsor Resort team to investigate the incident and are seeking information from anyone who was in the queue for the Coastguard HQ boat ride between approximately 11.30am and 12:45pm. The police have confirmed that they are not seeking any additional suspects in connection with the incident. The theme park has released a statement saying that it will continue to support Thames Valley Police in their ongoing investigation.
